content: The "Phantom Fuels Elimination Act of 2014" requires the production of advanced biofuel, biomass-based diesel, and cellulosic biofuel in the United States to meet renewable fuel program mandates. The "Phantom Fuels Elimination Act of 2014" mandates the production of advanced biofuel, biomass-based diesel, and cellulosic biofuel in the United States to meet renewable fuel program requirements. Amendments specify that these fuels must be produced in the United States and derived from renewable sources. Amendments to the Clean Air Act require the production of advanced biofuel in the US from renewable sources. Waivers may be granted if the projected volume of advanced biofuel production is insufficient. Amendments to the Clean Air Act require the production of advanced biofuel in the US from renewable sources. Waivers may be granted if the projected volume of biomass-based diesel production is less than the minimum required volume. Amendments to the Clean Air Act now include the production of advanced biofuel in the US from renewable sources. Waivers can be granted if the projected volume of biomass-based diesel production is below the required minimum volume. Elimination of corn ethanol mandate for renewable fuel is proposed. Amendments are made to the Clean Air Act regarding renewable fuel requirements, including the removal of a table and conforming amendments to clauses. Amendments to the Clean Air Act involve redesignating clauses, adjusting biofuel volume requirements, and mandating EPA regulations within 180 days of enactment. The amendments made by this section will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act.
